<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 378, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 171, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 366, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 171, 904, 230]]<|/det|>
0625/21 May/June 2025 45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 505, 262]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 278, 540, 322]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 338, 227, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 354, 905, 520]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 548, 218, 561]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 564, 568, 610]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
1 The speed–time graph for a racing car is divided into four sections, P, Q, R and S. The car starts the race but soon crashes into a wall of tyres.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[307, 116, 690, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 289, 775, 307]]<|/det|>
Which sections of the graph show that there is an acceleration that is changing?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 317, 128, 335]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 317, 270, 335]]<|/det|>
A P, Q, R and S

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 345, 141, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 343, 289, 361]]<|/det|>
B Q, R and S only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 370, 141, 387]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 369, 268, 387]]<|/det|>
C Q and R only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 396, 141, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 264, 413]]<|/det|>
D R and S only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 439, 97, 456]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 439, 641, 457]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 668, 670, 686]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 74, 920, 106]]<|/det|> 3 The diagrams show two metal blocks, X and Y , suspended from identical force meters. X and Y have identical dimensions. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 114, 626, 424]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 438, 472, 454]]<|/det|> Which statement about X and Y is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 466, 144, 482]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 465, 570, 482]]<|/det|> A They have different volumes and different weights. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 491, 144, 507]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 490, 548, 507]]<|/det|> B They have different volumes and equal weights. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 516, 144, 533]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 516, 527, 533]]<|/det|> C They have equal volumes and equal weights. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 543, 144, 559]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 542, 548, 559]]<|/det|> D They have equal volumes and different weights. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 586, 97, 602]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 586, 337, 603]]<|/det|> 4 A girl has a gold necklace. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 616, 638, 633]]<|/det|> Which apparatus does she need to find the density of the gold? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 644, 880, 790]]<|/det|>
balancemeasuring cylinderthermometerruler
A✓✓✓✓
B✓✓✓✗
C✓✓✗✗
D✓✗✗✗
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 817, 97, 834]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 817, 715, 834]]<|/det|> 5 A spring has a length of 25 cm when a load of 2.0 N is suspended from it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 847, 608, 864]]<|/det|> The spring has a length of 35 cm when a 7.0 N load is used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 877, 462, 894]]<|/det|> What is the spring constant of the spring? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 905, 732, 922]]<|/det|> A \(0.20 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{cm}\) B \(0.50 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{cm}\) C \(2.0 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{cm}\) D \(5.0 \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{cm}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
6 The diagrams \(E-H\) show a block of wood on a frictionless surface. In each diagram, the block has two forces acting on its sides.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 114, 920, 233]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 247, 504, 265]]<|/det|>
Which diagrams show the block in equilibrium?

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 276, 272, 293]]<|/det|>
A E, F, G and H

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 303, 289, 319]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 301, 288, 318]]<|/det|>
B E, G and H only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 328, 144, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 327, 262, 344]]<|/det|>
C E and F only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 354, 144, 370]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 353, 265, 370]]<|/det|>
D G and H only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 396, 97, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 396, 384, 414]]<|/det|>
7 Which statement is not correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 425, 631, 443]]<|/det|>
A the momentum of a system is conserved in all interactions

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 451, 420, 468]]<|/det|>
B impulse \(=\) change of momentum

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 478, 507, 495]]<|/det|>
C force acting \(=\) change of momentum \(\times\) time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 505, 396, 522]]<|/det|>
D momentum \(=\) mass \(\times\) velocity

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 549, 97, 566]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 549, 827, 567]]<|/det|>
8 A force acting on a moving ball causes its motion to change. This force stays constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 579, 725, 597]]<|/det|>
What makes the force produce a greater change in the motion of the ball?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 608, 144, 625]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 607, 453, 625]]<|/det|>
A decreasing the total mass of the ball

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 634, 460, 651]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 634, 463, 651]]<|/det|>
B increasing the temperature of the ball

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 660, 580, 677]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 660, 580, 677]]<|/det|>
C using a ball with a hollow centre but the same mass

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 687, 144, 704]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 686, 850, 703]]<|/det|>
D using a different material for the ball so that it has a lower density but the same mass

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 74, 918, 104]]<|/det|> 9 A farmer has two carts. The carts have the same weight, but one has four narrow wheels and the other has four wide wheels. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[308, 114, 690, 253]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 265, 682, 280]]<|/det|> Which cart wheels sink less into soft ground and what is the reason? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 293, 578, 420]]<|/det|>
cart wheelsreason
Anarrowgreater pressure on the ground
Bnarrowless pressure on the ground
Cwidegreater pressure on the ground
Dwideless pressure on the ground
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 448, 116, 465]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 448, 554, 465]]<|/det|> 10 A hot gas and a cool liquid are at the same pressure. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 479, 918, 510]]<|/det|> Which row describes the separation and the motion of the particles of a hot gas compared to those of a cool liquid? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 521, 692, 650]]<|/det|>
separation of gas particlesmotion of gas particles
Agreater than a cool liquidfaster than a cool liquid
Bgreater than a cool liquidslower than a cool liquid
Cless than a cool liquidfaster than a cool liquid
Dless than a cool liquidslower than a cool liquid
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 679, 116, 695]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[107, 679, 920, 710]]<|/det|> 11 A fixed mass of gas has a volume of \(1.2 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\) and is at a pressure of \(200 \mathrm{kPa}\). The gas expands at constant temperature to a volume of \(1.8 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 725, 426, 740]]<|/det|> What is the new pressure of the gas? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 752, 720, 767]]<|/det|> A \(120 \mathrm{kPa}\) B \(130 \mathrm{kPa}\) C \(300 \mathrm{kPa}\) D \(600 \mathrm{kPa}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 116, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 74, 662, 91]]<|/det|>
12 The specific heat capacity of solid P is greater than that of solid Q .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 393, 120]]<|/det|>
What does this statement mean?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 133, 144, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 131, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
A Less energy is needed to raise the temperature by 1 °C of unit mass of solid P than unit mass of solid Q .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 174, 144, 190]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 172, 782, 189]]<|/det|>
B Less energy is needed to melt unit mass of solid P than unit mass of solid Q .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 200, 144, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 198, 920, 230]]<|/det|>
C More energy is needed to raise the temperature by 1 °C of unit mass of solid P than unit mass of solid Q .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 240, 144, 256]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 238, 785, 255]]<|/det|>
D More energy is needed to melt unit mass of solid P than unit mass of solid Q .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 284, 116, 300]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 282, 690, 300]]<|/det|>
13 When water evaporates, what escapes from the surface of the water?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 312, 144, 328]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 311, 304, 327]]<|/det|>
A individual atoms

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 338, 321, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 337, 323, 354]]<|/det|>
B individual molecules

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 364, 304, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 364, 304, 380]]<|/det|>
C individual protons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 390, 310, 407]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 390, 310, 406]]<|/det|>
D tiny drops of water

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 435, 116, 451]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 433, 704, 451]]<|/det|>
14 A sealed container of gas is heated. The pressure of the gas increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 464, 549, 481]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains this increase in pressure?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 492, 144, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 491, 757, 508]]<|/det|>
A The forces of the gas particles striking the walls of the container increase.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 518, 144, 535]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 518, 887, 535]]<|/det|>
B The forces of attraction between the gas particles and the walls of the container increase.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 545, 144, 561]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 545, 625, 561]]<|/det|>
C The gas particles collide with each other more frequently.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 571, 800, 588]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 570, 800, 587]]<|/det|>
D The gas particles lose more energy when they strike the walls of the container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 616, 116, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 615, 816, 632]]<|/det|>
15 A student has a copper rod and a wooden rod. Both rods have the same dimensions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 644, 665, 661]]<|/det|>
The student puts one end of each rod into a beaker of crushed ice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 674, 744, 691]]<|/det|>
After a few minutes, the student picks up the rods by the ends not in the ice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 704, 350, 720]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 733, 144, 749]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 732, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
A The copper rod feels colder than the wooden rod because copper is a better conductor than wood.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 775, 144, 791]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 774, 920, 806]]<|/det|>
B The copper rod feels warmer than the wooden rod because copper is a better conductor than wood.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 817, 144, 833]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 816, 920, 848]]<|/det|>
C The wooden rod feels colder than the copper rod because wood is a better conductor than copper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 858, 144, 874]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 857, 920, 888]]<|/det|>
D The wooden rod feels warmer than the copper rod because wood is a better conductor than copper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 116, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 74, 623, 91]]<|/det|> 16 The diagram shows a black object X at constant temperature. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 819, 120]]<|/det|> The arrows represent the absorption and emission of thermal radiation at the surface. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 131, 598, 271]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 284, 918, 314]]<|/det|> Object Y is at the same constant temperature as X and is identical except that it has a white surface. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 328, 562, 345]]<|/det|> Which row correctly compares object X with object Y? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 357, 515, 501]]<|/det|>
rate of absorption for Xrate of emission for X
Ahigherhigher
Blowerhigher
Chigherlower
Dlowerlower

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 74, 843, 91]]<|/det|>
17 The diagram shows a cork with a weight attached so that the cork floats upright in water.

Transverse waves travel across the water from X to Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 357, 560, 373]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 386, 144, 402]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

\(\rightarrow \leftarrow\) right and left

<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 412, 290, 428]]<|/det|>
\(\uparrow \downarrow\) up and down

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 440, 144, 456]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 440, 307, 456]]<|/det|>
\(\rightarrow\) only to the right

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 467, 144, 483]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 467, 295, 483]]<|/det|>
\(\leftarrow\) only to the left

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 511, 114, 527]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 510, 554, 527]]<|/det|>
18 A thin converging lens is used as a magnifying glass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 541, 500, 557]]<|/det|>
How does the image compare with the object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 570, 144, 586]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 570, 295, 585]]<|/det|>
real and inverted

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 596, 144, 612]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 596, 287, 611]]<|/det|>
real and upright

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 622, 314, 637]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 622, 314, 637]]<|/det|>
virtual and inverted

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 648, 304, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 648, 304, 663]]<|/det|>
virtual and upright

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 116, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 74, 920, 106]]<|/det|> 19 The diagram shows two plane mirrors at \(90^{\circ}\) to each other. A ray of light is incident on one of the mirrors. The ray reflects off both mirrors before reaching a screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 567, 136]]<|/det|> At which labelled point does the ray reach the screen? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[325, 147, 675, 401]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 432, 114, 448]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 432, 651, 448]]<|/det|> 20 The speed of light in a material is \(50 \%\) of the speed of light in air. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 464, 477, 479]]<|/det|> What is the refractive index of the material? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 492, 133, 508]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 491, 185, 508]]<|/det|> 0.5 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 491, 314, 508]]<|/det|> B <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 491, 363, 508]]<|/det|> 2.0 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 491, 566, 508]]<|/det|> C \(6.0 \times 10^{8}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 491, 680, 508]]<|/det|> D \(1.5 \times 10^{8}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 537, 114, 554]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 537, 626, 553]]<|/det|> 21 A beam of white light is split into a spectrum of seven colours. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 568, 428, 584]]<|/det|> Which name is given to this process? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 596, 144, 612]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 596, 240, 611]]<|/det|> A diffraction <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 622, 243, 637]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 622, 243, 637]]<|/det|> B dispersion <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 648, 235, 663]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 648, 235, 663]]<|/det|> C reflection <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 674, 240, 689]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 674, 240, 689]]<|/det|> D refraction <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 719, 114, 735]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 719, 732, 734]]<|/det|> 22 Satellites are sometimes used to receive and re-transmit television signals. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 750, 740, 765]]<|/det|> Which row shows the type of satellite and the electromagnetic waves used? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 778, 504, 920]]<|/det|>
type of satelliteelectromagnetic waves used
Alow orbitinfrared
Blow orbitmicrowaves
Cgeostationaryinfrared
Dgeostationarymicrowaves

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 114, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 74, 692, 91]]<|/det|> 23 A sound wave travels through the air and strikes a solid block of steel. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 843, 120]]<|/det|> Some of the sound is reflected from the steel, and some is transmitted through the steel. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 134, 918, 165]]<|/det|> How does the speed and the wavelength of the sound in steel compare to the speed and the wavelength of the sound in air? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 178, 591, 306]]<|/det|>
speed in steelwavelength in steel
Aless than in airless than in air

The arrows represent the pattern and the direction of the magnetic field due to the magnets. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 376, 702, 477]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 494, 918, 526]]<|/det|> Which row identifies the magnetic pole at J , the magnetic pole at K and where the magnetic field is the strongest? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 537, 583, 681]]<|/det|>

description of electric fielddirection of electric field

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 320, 114, 337]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 320, 920, 352]]<|/det|> Copper wire is available in fixed lengths but in various diameters \(d\). Each wire has a different resistance \(R\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 365, 509, 383]]<|/det|> Which relationship between \(R\) and \(d\) is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 394, 144, 410]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 393, 398, 410]]<|/det|> \(R\) is directly proportional to \(d\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 419, 144, 435]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 418, 406, 435]]<|/det|> \(R\) is directly proportional to \(d^{2}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 445, 144, 462]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 444, 410, 462]]<|/det|> \(R\) is inversely proportional to \(d\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 471, 420, 488]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 470, 421, 488]]<|/det|> \(R\) is inversely proportional to \(d^{2}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 517, 114, 534]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 516, 920, 549]]<|/det|> The diagram shows three \(20 \Omega\) resistors, \(R_{1}, R_{2}\) and \(R_{3}\), and a switch S connected to a d.c. power supply. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 558, 687, 700]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 713, 263, 728]]<|/det|> Switch S is open. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 743, 517, 759]]<|/det|> The potential difference (p.d.) across \(R_{3}\) is 9.0 V . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 772, 546, 789]]<|/det|> What is the p.d. across \(R_{3}\) when switch S is closed? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 800, 144, 816]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 800, 200, 816]]<|/det|> 3.0 V <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 800, 364, 816]]<|/det|> B 6.0 V <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 800, 527, 816]]<|/det|> C 12 V <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 800, 690, 816]]<|/det|> D 27 V

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 444, 114, 460]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 444, 473, 460]]<|/det|> 32 A simple transformer contains an iron core. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 473, 573, 490]]<|/det|> What is the function of the iron core in the transformer? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 502, 144, 518]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 501, 652, 518]]<|/det|> A to conduct current from the primary coil to the secondary coil <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 528, 160, 544]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 528, 612, 544]]<|/det|> B to enable the secondary coil to act as an electromagnet <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 555, 816, 571]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 549, 816, 570]]<|/det|> C to ensure there is a high voltage between the primary coil and the secondary coil <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 580, 680, 596]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 578, 680, 596]]<|/det|> D to link the magnetic field in the primary coil to the secondary coil <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 624, 114, 640]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 624, 920, 655]]<|/det|> 33 In an alpha particle scattering experiment, a beam of alpha particles is fired at a very thin piece of gold foil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 668, 728, 685]]<|/det|> In which direction do most of the alpha particles travel after hitting the foil? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[317, 694, 680, 829]]<|/det|>

The background count rate is 32 counts/minute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 252, 561, 268]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 280, 314, 297]]<|/det|>
A 192 counts/minute

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 307, 144, 323]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 307, 314, 323]]<|/det|>
B 200 counts/minute

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 333, 144, 350]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 333, 314, 350]]<|/det|>

<label>36</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 402, 611, 419]]<|/det|>
36 Sodium-24 is a radioactive isotope that emits beta radiation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 432, 577, 449]]<|/det|>
Which nuclear equation shows how sodium-24 decays?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 466, 144, 483]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 466, 333, 483]]<|/det|>
A \(^{24}_{11}\mathrm {Na}\rightarrow ^{24}_{12}\mathrm {Mg}+\ ^{0}_{-1}\beta\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 494, 144, 510]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 494, 333, 510]]<|/det|>
B \(^{24}_{11}\mathrm {Na}\rightarrow ^{24}_{10}\mathrm {Ne}+\ ^{0}_{-1}\beta\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 521, 144, 538]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 521, 308, 538]]<|/det|>
C \(^{24}_{11}\mathrm {Na}\rightarrow ^{20}_{9}\mathrm {F}+\ ^{4}_{-1}\beta\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 549, 144, 566]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 549, 314, 566]]<|/det|>
D \(^{24}_{11}\mathrm {Na}\rightarrow ^{20}_{13}\mathrm {Al}+\ ^{4}_{-1}\beta\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 597, 114, 613]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 597, 797, 613]]<|/det|>
37 Which safety precautions must be taken when using a source of gamma radiation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 626, 696, 643]]<|/det|>
1 Reduce the distance between the source and the person.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 653, 596, 669]]<|/det|>
2 Reduce the time of exposure to the radiation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 679, 794, 695]]<|/det|>
3 Use a suitable shielding material between the source and the person.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 708, 144, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 708, 757, 725]]<|/det|>
A 1, 2 and 3 B 1 and 2 only C 1 and 3 only D 2 and 3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 116, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 74, 444, 91]]<|/det|> 38 A student defines three periods of time: <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 103, 608, 120]]<|/det|> - the time \(T_{S}\) taken for the Earth to orbit the Sun <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 129, 682, 146]]<|/det|> - the time \(T_{\mathrm{R}}\) taken for the Earth to rotate once on its axis <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 155, 628, 172]]<|/det|> - the time \(T_{\mathrm{M}}\) taken for the Moon to orbit the Earth. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 185, 744, 202]]<|/det|> Which row shows the shortest period of time and the longest period of time? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 214, 463, 358]]<|/det|>
shortest period of timelongest period of time
A\(T_{S}\)\(T_{R}\)
B\(T_{R}\)\(T_{S}\)
C\(T_{R}\)\(T_{M}\)
D\(T_{M}\)\(T_{S}\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 386, 116, 402]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 386, 510, 403]]<|/det|> 39 Which statement about the Universe is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 415, 144, 431]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 414, 504, 431]]<|/det|> A The Universe consists of 100 000 galaxies. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 441, 144, 457]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 440, 920, 473]]<|/det|> B Redshift is a decrease in the observed wavelength of electromagnetic radiation emitted from receding galaxies. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 481, 144, 497]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 481, 601, 497]]<|/det|> C Light emitted from distant galaxies appears redshifted. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 507, 144, 523]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 507, 881, 523]]<|/det|> D Redshift of the light from distant galaxies gives evidence that the Universe is contracting. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 551, 116, 567]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 551, 839, 567]]<|/det|> 40 Which statement about the cosmic microwave background radiation (CMBR) is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 580, 144, 596]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 579, 690, 596]]<|/det|> A CMBR now has a frequency higher than that of infrared radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 606, 141, 622]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 605, 579, 622]]<|/det|> B CMBR has always had exactly the same frequency. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 631, 144, 648]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 631, 520, 648]]<|/det|> C CMBR had a shorter wavelength in the past. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 658, 144, 674]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 657, 682, 674]]<|/det|> D CMBR was produced a long time after the Universe was formed.
